thread.title: Red Wings stun NHL-best Capitals in shoot-out, 3-2
thread.title_full: Red Wings stun NHL-best Capitals in shoot-out, 3-2

author: Detroit Free Press
title: Red Wings stun NHL-best Capitals in shoot-out, 3-2

organizations.name: getty images nick jensen of the red wings

text:
Red Wings stun NHL-best Capitals in shoot-out, 3-2 Wings squander two-goal lead, then take shoot-out on Zetterberg's goal to end five-game skid Post to Facebook Red Wings stun NHL-best Capitals in shoot-out, 3-2 Wings squander two-goal lead, then take shoot-out on Zetterberg's goal to end five-game skid   Freep.com: http://on.freep.com/2luLD9o   Join the Conversation To   Red Wings stun NHL-best Capitals in shoot-out, 3-2 Helene St. James , Detroit Free Press Published 5:09 p.m. ET Feb. 18, 2017 | Updated 2 minutes ago Facebook Posted! Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports Red Wings center Frans Nielsen is congratulated by teammates after scoring in the first period against the Capitals, Saturday, Feb. 18, 2017 in Detroit. Carlos Osorio, AP Red Wings goalie Petr Mrazek keeps an eye on the puck next to Justin Williams of the Capitals during the first period at Joe Louis Arena on Feb. 18, 2017 in Detroit. Gregory Shamus, Getty Images Brendan Smith of the Red Wings checks Alex Ovechkin of the Capitals during the first period at Joe Louis Arena on Feb. 18, 2017 in Detroit. Gregory Shamus, Getty Images Nick Jensen of the Red Wings tries to get around the stick of Lars Eller of the Capitals during the first period at Joe Louis Arena on Feb. 18, 2017 in Detroit. Gregory Shamus, Getty Images Feb 18, 2017; Detroit, MI, USA; Red Wings left wing Henrik Zetterberg skates with the puck defended by Capitals defenseman Matt Niskanen in the first period at Joe Louis Arena. Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports Feb 18, 2017; Detroit, MI, USA; Capitals defenseman Karl Alzner checks Red Wings left wing Henrik Zetterberg in the first period at Joe Louis Arena. Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports Feb 18, 2017; Detroit, MI, USA; Capitals defenseman Brooks Orpik and Red Wings center Darren Helm fight for position in front of Washington goalie Braden Holtby in the first period at Joe Louis Arena. Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports Feb 18, 2017; Detroit, MI, USA; Red Wings left wing Tomas Tatar (21) receives congratulations from teammates after scoring in the second period against the Capitals at Joe Louis Arena. Carlos Osorio, AP Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide Wings squander two-goal lead, then take shoot-out on Zetterberg's goal to end five-game skid Feb 18, 2017; Detroit, MI, USA; Capitals defenseman Karl Alzner checks Red Wings left wing Henrik Zetterberg in the first period at Joe Louis Arena. (Photo: Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports) 1 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Petr Mrazek again gave the Detroit Red Wings the chance they needed. 
Mrazek turned in a third straight strong start this afternoon at Joe Louis Arena, making 34 saves through overtime to lead the Wings to a 3-2 shoot-out victory over the Washington Capitals, who despite coming off their bye week still boasted the best record in the NHL. 
Box score 
In the shoot-out, Thomas Vanek scored first, T.J. Oshie shot wide, Frans Nielsen was stopped, Evgeny Kuznetsov converted, Andreas Athanasiou had too much speed going to get off a good shot, and Nicklas Backstrom was turned away by Mrazek. 
Tomas Tatar was turned away by Brad Holtby and Brett Connolly was stopped by Mrazek. Henrik Zetterberg scored on a backhand and Alex Ovechkin stopped. 
The Wings are trying to rise from the bottom of the Eastern Conference and into the playoff picture, now with 24 games left to do so. They play at Pittsburgh on Sunday. 
Related: Season slipping, it's time for Detroit Red Wings to eye future 
Goals from Nielsen and Tatar and 20 saves from Mrazek made it 2-1 going into the third period, which began with a full penalty kill. Steve Ott had a golden chance off a turnover but couldn’t best Braden Holtby. Henrik Zetterberg carried the puck behind the net and sent it out front only to have no teammate there. 
A fourth penalty kill materialized at 8:31. The Wings intercepted a weak pass attempt by Oveckin to cut down on the Capitals’ possession time. The Wings went back on the penalty kill with eight minutes to go, making the Wings shorthanded for six minutes of the period. Mrazek covered up the puck as Ovechkin and company swarmed after a rebound after making the initial save on Lars Eller with an outstretched left leg. 
A bad bounce made it a 2-2 game. Mrazek made a save only to have the puck bounce out and hit the stick of Daniel Winnik, ricocheting into an empty net. The Wings were outshot, 32-22 in regulation. 
Mrazek denied John Carlson with a glove save in overtime, after two teammates had lost their sticks. The Wings had the puck in the offensive zone the last minute but couldn't generate a shot. 
Mike Green, the team’s most productive defenseman, missed the game because of illness. 
Mrazek had to make two big saves in the opening minute, stopping first Oveckin and then kicking out Backstrom’s rebound attempt. Anthony Mantha promptly tested Holtby with a net-front attempt. Darren Helm created a good opportunity when he drove the puck deep into the offensive zone only to have Danny DeKeyser shoot over the net. 
A power play helped: Nielsen made it 1-0 when he skated to the left post, in position to tap in Zetterberg's bouncy pass from the right corner. The Wings stayed aggressive through a penalty kill, Mrazek made a couple of key saves, and Athanasiou got a good chance past the period’s midpoint. 
Riley Sheahan was tagged with a face-off violation in the last minute, requiring three saves from Mrazek, and spilling over by 1:22 into the second period. The Wings killed that off and then went back to attacking. Mantha used his powerful stride to create a chance off a John Carlson turnover,, skating the puck deep before feeding Zetterberg, who backhanded a pass between his legs to Tatar for a 2-0 lead at 3:33. 
Mrazek came through with one big save after another as the Caps pressed, deflecting a Marcus Johansson attempt off thee left pad. A second Detroit power play saw good possession. Among the next Mrazek highlights was stopping a Carlson slap shot from the left circle. The shutout bid ended with 1:24 to go when a Vanek turnover and then failure to pick up Zach Sanford enabled Sanford to halve Detroit’s lead, part of an 11-shot second period for the Capitals.
